title: Accessibility statement
heading1: Accessibility statement for ‘Stopping a probate application’ service
paragraph1: This service allows users to apply to stop an application for a grant of representation (also known as probate) online.
paragraph2: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:
list1-item1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
list1-item2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
list1-item3: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
list1-item4: navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
list1-item5: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
paragraph3: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
paragraph4: AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
paragraph5: The website uses the latest version of the GOV.UK Design System. In addition we’ve carried out internal testing to ensure that we’re in-line with or close to the latest accessibility standards.
paragraph6: Following our internal test, the following areas were recommended for further testing:
list2-item1: Navigating using character shortcuts - While we’ve tested with free screen readers for Mac and Chrome, different screen reader services will have different shortcuts and we haven’t been able to conclusively verify all of them.
list2-item2: Text spacing - We haven’t been able to verify that the service works for all users requiring larger text spacing.
list2-item3: Content on hover or focus - We haven’t been able to test that this works with users that have motor skill issues.
list2-item4: Focus visible - Some users may struggle to notice the focus indicator.
heading3: What to do if you cannot access parts of this website
paragraph7: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read or braille then email HMCTSforms@justice.gov.uk or phone:
paragraph9: Find out about call charges
paragraph10: We’ll consider your request and get back to you within 10 working days.
heading4: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
paragraph11: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems that are not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, phone:
paragraph12: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).
heading6: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
paragraph13: We provide a text relay service for people who are deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
paragraph14: Our registries have audio induction loops. When you submit your appeal you will be able to request a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter or foreign language interpreter.
heading7: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
paragraph15: HMCTS is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
paragraph16: The website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard due to the non-compliances listed below.
paragraph17: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
list3-item1: Navigating using character shortcuts - While we tested with MAC VoiceOver and ChromeVox, different screen reader services will have different shortcuts and we haven’t been able to conclusively verify all of them. This may not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.1.4.
list3-item2: Text spacing - We cannot confirm that the service works for those requiring larger text spacing. This may not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.12.
list3-item3: Content on hover or focus - We have not been able to verify with users that have motor skill issues. This may not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.13.
list3-item4: Focus visible - Some users may struggle to notice the focus indicator. This may not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.7.
paragraph18: Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) testing will take place in October 2019 and we commit to fixing any issues raised by October 2020.
heading9: Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations
paragraph19: PDFs, documents and attachments to email notifications published before 23 September 2018 may not meet accessibility standards. For example, they may not be structured so they’re accessible to a screen reader.
heading9-2: Third party content that’s under someone else’s control

list4-item5: The webchat application which provides live service support for users
paragraph25: We carried out internal testing in April 2019 against the WCAG 2.1 standard.
paragraph26: All the issues raised during testing were subsequently fixed.
paragraph27: Further testing with the digital accessibility team is planned for October 2019 and we commit to being fully compliant with WCAG 2.1 AA standard by October 2020.
heading11: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
paragraph28: This website is continually tested using accessibility software. Any new features which are introduced will also be tested internally or with the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC).
paragraph29: We will be fixing any issues raised in our scheduled DAC test by October 2020.
paragraph30: This statement was prepared on 23 September 2019. It was last updated on 24 September 2019.
